Introduction

Anal cancer is a rare gastrointestinal malignancy that arises in the anus or anal canal and is strongly associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.  The risk is highest in individuals who engage in receptive anal intercourse, particularly men who have sex with men, and in those with advanced HIV infection (due to immunosuppression and a higher prevalence of persistent HPV infection).  The most common histologic subtype is squamous cell carcinoma.  Anal cancer often presents with bleeding, pain, and a sensation of anal fullness; physical examination classically shows a nodular, exophytic mass or an ulcerated lesion.

Pathogenesis



The majority of anal cancers are linked to oncogenic strains of human papillomavirus (HPV), a nonenveloped, double-stranded DNA virus transmitted through oral, vaginal, or anal sexual contact.  HPV causes disease by infecting and replicating within squamous epithelial cells.  Its oncogenic potential arises following integration into the host genome and subsequent expression of viral oncoproteins E6 and E7.  These proteins inactivate the tumor suppressors p53 and Rb, respectively, disrupting cell cycle control and promoting neoplastic transformation (

figure 1
).  HPV types 16 and 18 are most strongly associated with malignancy.



In addition, chronic inflammation and immunosuppression can further drive malignant progression in the anal epithelium.  Chronic inflammation (eg, due to inflammatory bowel disease) promotes repeated cycles of injury and repair, generating DNA-damaging reactive species and fostering abnormal cell proliferation.  Immunosuppression (eg, HIV infection) impairs immune surveillance, reducing the body's ability to eliminate precancerous or HPV-infected cells and allowing oncogenic changes to persist.

Risk factors



  • HPV infection (especially types 16 and 18).
  • Receptive anal intercourse.
  • Multiple sexual partners.
  • Chronic immunosuppression (eg, HIV infection, post-organ transplant).
  • Smoking.
  • History of cervical, vulvar, or vaginal dysplasia or cancer.
  • Chronic inflammatory conditions (eg, Crohn disease, anal fissure) affecting the perianal area.

Pathology



Most anal cancers are squamous cell carcinomas (SCCs), characterized histologically by large, eosinophilic, hyperchromatic squamous cells with scant cytoplasm arranged in irregular islands.  Features such as nuclear atypia and prominent keratinization, including keratin pearls, are typically observed (

).



SCCs generally arise from precancerous lesions known as anal squamous intraepithelial lesions (ASILs), which originate at the squamocolumnar junction and have a well-documented association with HPV types 16 and 18 (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).  ASIL is classified as low-grade or high-grade based on the extent of nuclear atypia and mitotic activity seen on biopsy.  Whereas low-grade ASIL may be monitored in select cases, treatment is strongly recommended for high-grade ASIL due to its potential for malignant progression.



Less common types of anal tumors include adenocarcinoma (arising from anal glands or rectal mucosa), perianal melanoma, and neuroendocrine carcinomas.

Clinical presentation



Symptoms of anal cancer may be subtle and nonspecific, often leading to delays in diagnosis.  Common clinical manifestations include:



  • Rectal bleeding.
  • Anal pain, pressure, or discomfort.
  • Palpable mass (eg, exophytic, nodular) or ulcer at the anal verge (
    image 1
    ).
  • Pruritus ani (itching).
  • Tenesmus.
  • Incontinence (rare).
  • Painless regional lymphadenopathy:  Firm, nontender inguinal or femoral lymph nodes.

Differential diagnosis



  • Hemorrhoids:  Commonly present with rectal bleeding, anal discomfort, and perianal itching.  On examination, a soft to firm, compressible mass may be palpable at the anal verge.  However, ulcerated or nodular lesions and regional lymphadenopathy are not typical features.
  • Anal fissure:  Typically associated with severe, sharp pain during bowel movements and a small amount of bright red rectal bleeding.  Lesions usually appear as linear tears, most commonly in the posterior midline, and generally heal within 6 weeks.
  • Anal fistulas:  Often develop as a complication of a previous anorectal abscess and are characterized by chronic purulent perianal drainage and intermittent rectal pain.  They typically present as small, external openings near the anus, sometimes with induration or tenderness along the tract.
  • Condyloma acuminata (genital warts) (
    image 2
    ):  Caused by low-risk HPV types, these lesions usually present as asymptomatic, skin-colored, verrucous papules or plaques.  They are not typically ulcerated, and rectal bleeding is uncommon.
  • Chancroid (caused by Haemophilus ducreyi) (
    image 3
    ):  Sexually transmitted infection causing painful genital ulcers with ragged edges, a gray-yellow exudate, and marked, tender inguinal lymphadenitis that can suppurate; painless lymphadenopathy is not characteristic.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of anal cancer begins with a thorough history to assess for risk factors (eg, HIV, receptive anal intercourse), followed by a comprehensive physical examination that includes a digital rectal examination (DRE), anoscopy, and palpation of regional (eg, inguinal, femoral) lymph nodes.  Any suspicious lesions in the anus or distal rectum should be biopsied for histopathologic evaluation to confirm the diagnosis.

Laboratory evaluation



The laboratory workup for anal cancer may include HIV and HPV testing due to the high association between anal cancer and these infections.  Women who are diagnosed with anal cancer should have a thorough gynecologic evaluation (with biopsy as needed) to rule out associated HPV-related cervical cancer.

Imaging studies



Once anal carcinoma is confirmed via biopsy, imaging plays a critical role in staging and treatment planning.  The primary goals are to assess the size and local extent of the primary tumor (T-staging), evaluate regional lymph node involvement (N-staging), and detect distant metastases (M-staging).  Imaging modalities include MRI of the pelvis (preferred), CT scan of the chest/abdomen/pelvis, PET scan, and endoanal ultrasonography.

Management



Most anal cancers are treated with chemotherapy and radiation (ie, chemoradiation) rather than surgery.  Chemoradiation has a high cure rate and reduces the risk of surgically induced sphincter injury and dysfunction, a debilitating complication of operative excision.



Surgical intervention (eg, abdominoperineal resection) is generally reserved for salvage therapy in patients with persistent or recurrent disease following definitive chemoradiation.

Prognosis



The prognosis for anal cancer is generally favorable with early detection and standard treatment, though outcomes vary significantly based on the stage at diagnosis.  The 5-year survival rate for localized disease (cancer confined to the anal area) is approximately 80%.  For cases with regional spread (involving nearby structures or lymph nodes), survival rate decreases to around 60%-70%.  In patients with distant metastases (spread to organs such as the liver or lungs), the 5-year survival rate drops to approximately 30%.

Prevention



Primary prevention strategies for anal cancer include safe sexual practices (eg, consistent condom use), HPV vaccination (recommended for all adolescents and at-risk adults) (

), and smoking cessation.



Regular screening (eg, digital rectal examinations) and, in some cases, anal cytology (analogous to Pap smears), may be considered for high-risk populations.  These include patients with HIV, men who have sex with men, solid organ transplant recipients, and women with a history of cervical cancer.

Summary



Anal cancer (

) is a relatively uncommon malignancy that is strongly associated with HPV infection.  It typically presents with bleeding, pain, and a palpable anal mass or ulceration.  The diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy and imaging (eg, MRI), which allows for cancer staging and treatment planning.  Most patients are managed with chemoradiation.  The prognosis is favorable with early-stage detection.  Prevention strategies include HPV vaccination and safe sex practices.
